Definitions.Definition_Content: Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
An endomorphism of a ring $R$ is a homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
An automorphism of a ring $R$ is an isomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The kernel of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$, is defined as $\{a \in R ; \varphi(a)=0\}$, which is an ideal in $R$.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.

Let $R$ be a ring and $\mathfrak{a}$ an ideal in $R$. The factor ring, or residue class ring, $R / \mathfrak{a}$, is defined initially as an abelian group by viewing $\mathfrak{a}$ as a (normal) subgroup of the additive group of $R$. The elements of $R / \mathfrak{a}$ are all residue classes of type $x+\mathfrak{a}$ for $x \in R$, where addition is given by $(x+\mathfrak{a})+(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x+y)+\mathfrak{a}$ and multiplication by $(x+\mathfrak{a}) \cdot(y+\mathfrak{a})=(x \cdot y)+\mathfrak{a}$. The ring properties of $R$ carry over to $R / \mathfrak{a}$.
A proper ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a prime ideal if for elements $a, b \in R$, $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ implies $a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$.

A proper ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a maximal ideal if for any ideal $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ that contains $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{a}$ must be either $\mathfrak{m}$ or $R$.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. Then: (i) $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$ is an ideal in $R$. (ii) $\operatorname{im} \varphi$ is a subring of $R'$. (iii) $\varphi$ induces a group homomorphism $R^{*} \longrightarrow R^{* *}$ between the multiplicative groups of units in $R$ and $R'$.
Let $K$ be a field and $R$ a ring, $R \neq 0$. Then every homomorphism $\varphi: K \longrightarrow R$ is injective. In particular, every homomorphism of fields is injective.

Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism and $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ an ideal satisfying $\mathfrak{a} \subset \operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then there exists a unique ring homomorphism $\bar{\varphi}: R / \mathfrak{a} \longrightarrow R'$ such that the diagram is commutative. Furthermore, $\operatorname{im} \bar{\varphi}=\operatorname{im} \varphi$, $\operatorname{ker} \bar{\varphi}=\pi(\operatorname{ker} \varphi)$, and $\operatorname{ker} \varphi=\pi^{-1}(\operatorname{ker} \bar{\varphi})$. In particular, $\bar{\varphi}$ is injective if and only if $\mathfrak{a}=\operatorname{ker} \varphi$.
If $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is a surjective ring homomorphism, then $R'$ is canonically isomorphic to $R / \operatorname{ker} \varphi$.
The following conditions are equivalent for $m \in \mathbb{Z}, m>0$: (i) $m$ is a prime number. (ii) $\mathbb{Z} / m \mathbb{Z}$ is an integral domain. (iii) $\mathbb{Z} / m \mathbb{Z}$ is a field.

Let $R$ be a ring. (i) An ideal $\mathfrak{p} \subset R$ is prime if and only if $R / \mathfrak{p}$ is an integral domain. (ii) An ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subset R$ is maximal if and only if $R / \mathfrak{m}$ is a field. In particular, every maximal ideal is prime.
An ideal in $\mathbb{Z}$ is prime if and only if it is of type $p \mathbb{Z}$ for a prime number $p$ or for $p=0$. An ideal in $\mathbb{Z}$ is maximal if and only if it is a nonzero prime ideal.

Let $R$ be a ring and $\mathfrak{a}_{1}, \ldots, \mathfrak{a}_{n} \subset R$ pairwise coprime ideals. Then the homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R / \mathfrak{a}_{1} \times \ldots \times R / \mathfrak{a}_{n}$ is surjective and satisfies $\operatorname{ker} \varphi=\mathfrak{a}_{1} \cap \ldots \cap \mathfrak{a}_{n}$. It induces an isomorphism $R / \bigcap_{i=1}^{n} \mathfrak{a}_{i} \xrightarrow{\sim} \prod_{i=1}^{n} R / \mathfrak{a}_{i}$.

Let $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}$ be integers that are pairwise relatively prime. Then the system of simultaneous congruences $x \equiv x_{i} \bmod a_{i}, i=1, \ldots, n$, is solvable for arbitrary integers $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in \mathbb{Z}$, and the solution $x$ is unique modulo $a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. Therefore, the set of all solutions forms a residue class of type $x+a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n} \mathbb{Z}$.
